docs.title: LSL.Enumerables.MarkdownTables
docs.text:
This library provides methods to generate a markdown table from a strongly typed IEnumerable<T>

The following example uses all the defaults:

var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>
{
    new("Key1", "Value1"),
    new("Key2", "Value2"),
    new("Key3", null)
}.ToMarkdownTable();

/* result will contain:

| Key   | Value   |
| :---- | :------ |
| Key1  | Value1  |
| Key2  | Value2  |
| Key3  | `null`  |
*/

docs.title: Defaults
docs.text:
• All top-level public properties that are simple types are output
  • Numbers are justified to the right.
  • Header names are the names of each property
  • DateTime and DateTimeOffset properties use the G format string (e.g. en-GB would show 20/02/2020 23:00:00 for 20th Feb 2020 at 11PM)
    • If there is no time portion then the d format string is used to only output the date.
  • Numeric data types will use the N2 format string (e.g. en-GB would show 2,123.22 for a decimal value of 2123.22)
    • all intrinsic integer values will use the N0 format string
  • null values will be output as `null`

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The options for the mark down table builder can setup three main areas:

Behaviour Notes Value Transformers These transform an object value into a string Property metadata provider Generates PropertyMetaData from a PropertyInfo instance Default output The output that is returned when an empty enumerable is used. It defaults to null

docs.title: Empty enumerable output
docs.text:
The following code overrides the default of returning null to return No Data

var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>()
    .ToMarkdownTable(c => c.UseEmptyResult("No Data"));

/* result will be: No Data */

docs.title: Default meta data provider
docs.text: The default meta data provider can be configured with extra options such as excluding specific properties as below:

docs.title: Exclude properties by name
docs.text:
var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>
{
    new("Key1", "Value1")
}
.ToMarkdownTable(c => c
    .UseDefaultPropertyMetaDataProvider(c => c.ExcludeProperties("Value")));

/* result will be
| Key   |
| :---- |
| Key1  |
*/

Info

Multiple properties can be passed into ExcludeProperties

docs.title: Exclude properties by expression
docs.text:
var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>
{
    new("Key1", "Value1")
}
.ToMarkdownTable(c => c
    .UseDefaultPropertyMetaDataProvider(c => c
        .ForClass<KeyValuePair<string, string>>(c => c
            .ExcludeProperties((p => p.Key)))));

/* result will be
| Value   |
| :------ |
| Value1  |
*/

Info

Multiple properties can be passed into ExcludeProperties

docs.title: Include properties by name
docs.text:
var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>
{
    new("Key1", "Value1")
}
.ToMarkdownTable(c => c
    .UseDefaultPropertyMetaDataProvider(c => c.IncludeProperties("Value")));

/* result will be
| Value   |
| :------ |
| Value1  |
*/

Info

Multiple properties can be passed into IncludeProperties

docs.title: Include properties by expression
docs.text:
var result = new List<KeyValuePair<string, string>>
{
    new("Key1", "Value1")
}
.ToMarkdownTable(c => c
    .UseDefaultPropertyMetaDataProvider(c => c
        .ForClass<KeyValuePair<string, string>>(c => c
            .IncludeProperties((p => p.Key)))));

/* result will be
| Value   |
| :------ |
| Value1  |

Info

Multiple properties can be passed into IncludeProperties

docs.title: DateTime Extensions
docs.text:
There are extension methods available to check if a DateTime or DateTimeOffset are deemed date only.

Other methods are also provided for formatting. These methods are used by the TimeDetectingDateTimeValueTransformer

docs.title: IsDateOnly
docs.text:
Checks if a DateTime or DateTimeOffset is date only i.e. the time values are all zero.

var isDateOnly = new DateTime(2010, 1, 1).IsDateOnly();
var isDateOnly2 = new DateTime(2010, 1, 1, 13, 0, 0).IsDateOnly();

/*
    isDateOnly will be true
    isDateOnly2 will be false
*/

docs.title: ToStringWithEmptyTimeDetection
docs.text:
Returns a string representation of a DateTme or DateTimeOffset using the given date formats.

If the source date time value has no time component then the dateOnlyFormat will be used to generate the string, otherwise the dateTimeFormat will be used.

var first = new DateTime(2010, 1, 1)
    .ToStringWithEmptyTimeDetection("G", "d");

var second = new DateTime(2010, 1, 1, 13, 0, 0)
    .ToStringWithEmptyTimeDetection("G", "d");

/*
    first will be 01/01/2010
    second will be 01/01/2010 13:00:00
*/

docs.title: Expression Extensions
docs.text: There are extension methods available to get the name or PropertyInfo of a property from an expression.

docs.title: GetPropertyInfo
docs.text:
Returns the PropertyInfo of the property specified by the source expression

public class MyClass
{
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }

    public static PropertyInfo GetPropertyInfo(
        Expression<Func<MyClass, object>> expression)
    {
        return expression.GetPropertyInfo();
    }
}

var propertyInfo = MyClass.GetPropertyInfo(c => c.Name);
/*
    propertyInfo will contain the PropertyInfo instance for the "Name" property
*/

docs.title: GetPropertyName
docs.text:
Returns the property name of the property specified by the source expression

public class MyClass
{
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }

    public static string GetPropertyName(
        Expression<Func<MyClass, object>> expression)
    {
        return expression.GetPropertyName();
    }
}

var propertyName = MyClass.GetPropertyInfo(c => c.Name);
/*
    propertyName will be "Name"
*/

docs.title: PropertyInfo Extensions
docs.text: There are extension methods available to reuse existing behviour when defining custom property meta data providers.

docs.title: GetJustification
docs.text:
Get's the Justification of a property based on its type. Any numeric type will be justified right. All other types will be justified left.

public class MyClass
{
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }
}

var idJustification = typeof(MyClass).GetProperty("Id").GetJustification();
var nameJustification = typeof(MyClass).GetProperty("Name").GetJustification();

/*
    idJustification will be Justification.Right
    nameJustification will be Justification.Left
*/

docs.title: IsSimpleType
docs.text:
Returns true if the property is deemed to be a simple type.

The property type is considered simple if one of the following is true:

  1. Is a primitive
  2. Is a value type
  3. Is an enum
  4. Is a string
  5. Is a decimal
public class MyClass
{
    public int Id { get; set; }
    public string Name { get; set; }
}

var idIsSimple = typeof(MyClass).GetProperty("Id").IsSimpleType();
var nameIsSimple = typeof(MyClass).GetProperty("Name").IsSimpleType();

/*
    idIsSimple will be true
    nameIsSimple will be true
*/

docs.title: ResolveValueTransformerFromAttributes
docs.text:
Mainly used internally, but has been exposed to allow custom meta data providers to re-use the following attributes:

Attribute Notes NumberValueTransformerAttribute Applies a number value transformer to the property DateTimeValueTransformerAttribute Applies a date time value transformer to the property TimeDetectingDateTimeValueTransformerAttribute Applies a time detecting value transformer to the property

Warning

Application of a value transformer to a property takes precedence over the global defaults for your builder.

docs.title: ResolveOutputAllowedFromAttributesAndType
docs.text:
Returns a value indicating as to whether a property should be outputted.

It initially checks the type is a simple type but can be overridden with the application of the IncludeInOutputAttribute.
